deal.dealname: Astron Systems Ltd - Pitch for investment

properties.description: Not just another rocket company. Affordable, fast, flexible small payload orbital launch and return with the first 100% reusable small lift rockets
properties.how_does_your_company_use_innovation__th: The nature of what we are doing is naturally highly innovative. We have a new propulsion system design we've developed (and patents filed), and are leading the way as the first building 100% reusability in a small lift rocket.
properties.how_does_your_product_contribute_to_a_he: Space directly is infrastructure that helps humanity on earth, especially for small payloads like our customers are.
properties.name: Astron Systems Ltd
properties.please_expand: Looking for capital, plus the media visbility and experience of Steven and team to help take this venture to a world leader and decacorn+ company.
properties.what_best_describes_your_stage_of_busine: I have a business that I want to scale
properties.what_is_your_usp__what_makes_you_differe: Actually being commercially competitive 5 years from now within the small lift launch market. That stems from 100% reusability, good architecture design, and our highly reusable propulsion system we've developed.
properties.what_sector_is_your_business_product_: Science & Technology (including Space, Biotech and AI)
properties.where_is_your_business_based_: UK but wanting to scale to US

structured_data.executive_summary: Astron Systems is building the first 100% reusable small-lift class rocket for affordable, fast, and flexible rides to orbit and back for small payloads. The company aims to cut costs by 5x and lead time by 10x, enabling small satellites to launch exactly when and where needed. They have secured >$360M/year in LOIs, >$1B/year in informal interest, and 4+ commercial launches booked. Their key innovation is small long lifetime performant rocket engines with patents filed and prototype hardware built. They're raising $2.7M with a projected exit of >$10B and total capex to cashflow positivity of $170M.
structured_data.problem_statement: Small satellite launches today are limited by expensive and inflexible rideshare missions with little orbit destination control. Current options have high costs, limited orbit flexibility, poor schedule flexibility, and long lead times (approximately 18 months).
structured_data.solution: Astron Systems is building the first 100% reusable small rocket (up to 360kg payload to LEO) that cuts cost by 5x and lead time by 10x, enabling small satellites to launch exactly when and where needed. The solution also enables regular and affordable medium duration space access and return services for small payloads at >5x lower price, and provides essential defense mission capabilities including point-to-point rocket cargo delivery and tactically responsive launch.
structured_data.product_service_description: A 100% reusable small-lift class rocket with up to 360kg payload capacity to Low Earth Orbit. The key enabling technology is a long lifetime rocket engine with >100x theoretical lifetime improvement. The system includes a hybrid electric turbopump unit with the first prototype cryogenic pump testing systems. The rocket enables direct-to-destination services with rapid launch times specifically tailored for small satellite operators.
structured_data.market_size_opportunity: Over 2,000 smallsats are expected to launch annually in the next decade. The smallsat launch market is valued at $34B for 2023-2032. Additionally, there's a >$22B market for in-space manufacturing from 2033 (microgravity and vacuum exposure services). Applications include climate monitoring, agriculture improvements, pharmaceuticals, weather, and communications.
structured_data.business_model: The company generates revenue through launch services with projected net profit margins of 40-50% by 2032. Revenue streams include single contract unresponsive launches, recurring contracts, responsive launches, and secondary pump sales. They project >$200M annual revenue by 2031 and >$1B annual revenue from 2036, with first test launch in 2028 and net cash flow positive thereafter.
structured_data.team: The founding team includes Eddie Brown (CEO, Engineer with experience in Titan deployable heatshield analysis and design, Imperial rocketry upper engine lead, and 10+ years commercial software experience), Kieran Jones-Tett (COO, CFO, Engineer with experience in URA Thrusters as Lead HET Engineer and spacecraft electric propulsion novel thruster design), and Rafal Sokolowski (CTO, Engineer with experience at Oxford Space Systems as Space Mechanism Engineer and Imperial rocketry propulsion lead). They are supported by advisors Gregory Krauland (led SpaceX Falcon 9 Stage 2 Development), Greg Autry (former NASA White House Liaison), Gautier Brunet (Loft Orbital VP of sales), and Benjamin Lenoir (Elia Product Manager).
structured_data.traction_milestones: The company has secured over $620K in funding to date (approximately 60% private capital, 40% non-dilutive funding). They have built and tested the first prototype of key enabling new propulsion technology, including a turbopump prototype with under $360K total spent since founding. They have established key development partnerships for heat shield and recovery systems with industry leaders. They have secured >$360M/year in LOIs, >$1B/year in informal interest, and 4+ commercial launches booked with customers.
structured_data.financials_projections: The company projects first test launch in 2028, net profit margin of 40-50% by 2032, >$200M annual revenue by 2031, and >$1B annual revenue from 2036. They expect to achieve ≥100 launches/year by 2031 and become net cash flow positive with total funding of approximately $170M. The exit valuation is projected at >$10B based on likely exit point DCF and 10% discount rate, with ROI for seed projected at >400x.
structured_data.funding_ask_use_of_funds: Raising $2.7M seed round for continuing rocket engine R&D, including second generation pump designs and first thrust chamber design manufacturing, testing, and building towards a first full breadboard rocket engine within 12 months. Funds will also cover up to 24 months of salaries and overheads, growing the team from 4 to 11 full-time employees, use of existing third-party test facilities, and upgrades to Astron Systems' test facility on Wescott Venture Park (UK).
structured_data.competition: The competitive landscape includes many companies building outdated small lift launch vehicles, while Astron is leading the way with 100% reusable small lift capability. Current competitors include Rocket Lab Electron (today's leading small-lift launcher with 300kg to orbit), various companies developing small-lift launchers, and larger players like SpaceX with their Falcon 9 and Starship. Astron positions itself as the leader in bringing 100% reusability to the small-lift segment (360kg to orbit).
structured_data.go_to_market_strategy: The company has already secured customer validation with LOIs and informal interest. Their go-to-market strategy includes negotiating deals for the first spaceport, proactively selling launches, converting to firm orders (Launch Service Agreements), and booking commercial customers for launches. They plan to front-load de-risking of the greatest perceived technical risks (propulsion system, re-entry, recovery) and have a low CAPEX cost to market approach by working with proven suppliers for key subsystems and leveraging the natural advantage of R&D and manufacturing costs in the UK and Europe.

founder_profiles.name: Eddie Brown
founder_profiles.background_summary: Eddie Brown is a highly technical founder with a strong academic and professional background in aerospace and software engineering. He holds a First Class Master's degree in Aeronautics with Spacecraft Engineering from Imperial College London, where he was on the Dean's List, and gained early leadership experience as a Propulsion Engineering Team Lead for the university's rocketry group. His credibility is further bolstered by experience at notable tech companies like Darktrace and MathWorks, and most significantly, his current venture, Astron Systems, is a graduate of the Techstars Space 2024 accelerator. Eddie's content on LinkedIn establishes him as a founder with a clear, deeply-held, and contrarian vision for the space industry. His posts are direct, opinionated, and focused on a singular mission: proving that 100% rocket reusability is the only viable future for commercial space launch. He actively debunks what he considers industry misconceptions and advocates for higher standards in sustainability and technology. While his audience is niche, his voice is that of a subject matter expert with a strong founder-led point of view, signaling significant brand potential as a leader in the European space-tech ecosystem.

previous_companies.description: Leading a space technology company focused on 100% rocket reusability. Graduate of Techstars Space 2024 accelerator.

investment_criteria_assessment.assessment_summary: Eddie Brown is a highly technical and mission-driven founder with a strong academic background and experience at notable tech companies. His current venture, Astron Systems, is well-aligned with focus industries and demonstrates a compelling, founder-led vision for the future of space technology. However, based on available data, he does not appear to have founded a relevant company prior to Astron Systems.

market_analysis.industry_overview: The Science & Technology sector in the UK encompasses a broad range of activities, including advanced research, development, and commercialization in fields such as space technology, biotechnology, and artificial intelligence (AI). The UK has a rich history of scientific innovation and remains a global leader in these sectors, with significant contributions to aerospace, pharmaceuticals, and digital technologies. The sector is characterized by a strong academic base, robust public and private investment, and a vibrant startup ecosystem.
market_analysis.target_market_segment: Key customer segments include government agencies (e.g., UK Space Agency, NHS), large enterprises in pharmaceuticals and aerospace, research institutions, universities, technology startups, and investors seeking innovation in biotech, AI, and space technology.
market_analysis.market_size_tam: Estimates for the combined Science & Technology (including Space, Biotech, and AI) market in the UK exceed £100 billion annually, with biotech alone valued at over £7.1 billion, AI at £16.9 billion, and the space sector at £16.5 billion as of 2023.
market_analysis.market_size_sam: The serviceable addressable market (SAM) for innovative solutions and services in these sectors is estimated at £30-40 billion, focusing on organizations actively investing in R&D, digital transformation, and advanced manufacturing.
market_analysis.market_size_som: A realistic SOM for a new entrant targeting niche applications (e.g., AI for healthcare, biotech for diagnostics, or satellite data analytics) is estimated at £100-300 million, depending on focus and go-to-market strategy.
market_analysis.market_growth_rate_cagr: The overall sector is projected to grow at a CAGR of 7-10% through 2028, with AI and biotech segments expected to outpace the average (AI: 12-15%, Biotech: 10-12%, Space: 8-10%).
key_market_trends: Rapid adoption of AI and machine learning across industries, especially healthcare, finance, and manufacturing.
Growth in private and public investment in space technology, including satellite communications and Earth observation.
Expansion of biotech innovation, particularly in genomics, diagnostics, and personalized medicine.
Increased focus on sustainability and green technologies, including clean energy and climate tech.
Rising importance of data security, ethics, and regulatory compliance in AI and biotech applications.
market_analysis.competitor_landscape_summary: The UK Science & Technology market is highly competitive, featuring a mix of established multinationals, innovative startups, and leading research institutions. Key players include both sector-specific leaders and diversified technology companies. The market is characterized by strong venture capital activity, frequent collaborations between academia and industry, and a growing number of scale-ups, particularly in AI and biotech.
